content.description:
Strenuous moves and bad feet at the crux, but somehow very satisfying at the same time.  Book describes starting low and left and climbing up and right on the face, mirroring the slab that rises below you.   

  We also TR'ed the arete going straight up the left side, maybe 5.8 and really fun that way as well.  Not much pro that way.
content.protection: Toprope.  Or, bring your small gear for an R rated outing.
content.location: Left arete to start, move up and right onto the face and up from there. Swartling describes going into right side vertical crack, then if you want to protect it you will likely need to then go back left again to the other crack and up after placing gear in the right side crack.

climbs.name: Sleestak
climbs.fa: Swartling & Mayer p.164, route not described but near  13 on diagram 36E.

content.description: Climb right slanting crack with many side pulls and ledges off to either side. After getting to final ledge edge on right climb straight up the remaining short steep face over the top.
content.protection: Plenty of small to medium sized wires or cams.  One shallow .5 C4 above the head on the right side below top to protect the final jug pulls.
content.location: Where the access gully to the Ramsay's area empties out, turn skier's right. You are there!    Small tower with inviting little right slanted crack and ledges.

content.description: Unnamed 5.4 in the book this is a good link up with Bloody Shin below.
content.location: Left side of Ramsay's Pinnacle. It's the easy crack system.

content.description:
Start in the center of the face, and contrive a way to stay centered. 

  Swartling & Mayer suggest there is a 5.7 here ... maybe if you start on the left-hand side?
content.location:
As you come down the access gully, and exit the "canyon", the first wall on your left.  It faces out. 

  The top-out is about 15-20 feet off the main East Bluff trail.

content.description: Ramsay's Ramp is the longest route on the pinnacle. It starts with a little boulder problem and a hidden hold. You can also skip the boulder problem and traverse in from the left. Finish on the left side of the chock-stone on top of the pinnacle.
content.location: On the southeast corner of Ramsay's Pinnacle.

content.description:
Big (but sloping) ledges near the right edge of the face. 

  Pretty fun!
content.location: Right side of the wall with "Burt's Beta" and "Pit Start".

content.description: Start at the base of the wall.  Bouldery moves take you up and right to the obvious finger slot.  Then onto the big ledge, your one good rest.  Finish up the central crack to the top of the tower.
content.location: At the bottom of the access gully, skier's right (north).  The obvious crack up the center of the face.

content.description: Climb the arête and crack up to 1/2 way point, then tackle the "in your face" hanging arête at the top.   There is an easier finish at the top that goes left.
content.protection: Small to medium cams and wired stoppers.  Mostly found mid sized cam placements up inside many cool deep openings under slanted flakes.  The top is a tad run-out!
content.location: Little face on the right as climber descends the Ramsay's Pinnacle area gully access about 20 yards from the gully top.  The top of this little wall is also very bluff top.

content.description: Pretty "blah" of a route. Take a lap for fitness' sake.
content.location: Face in the middle of Ramsay's Pinnacle, left of Ramsay's Ramp.

content.description:
Lots of smallish edges out on the face.  Decent gear but you may have to think a little about it. 

  Reminds me of "The Ramp" in Hawk's Nest, only without the sandbag start, and more sustained.
content.location: Just left of "Bloody Shine", the shallow dihedral above the very green face.

content.description: Start up the wide crack, the split between two towers.  After you pass the off-width move, move right into the beautiful dihedral and follow it to the top.
content.location:
Where the access gully to the Ramsay's area empties out, turn skier's left.  You are there! 

  Tops out maybe 15 feet from the main trail.

content.description: Climb the obvious arete finishing on the right side. Reachy at the crux unfortunately.
content.location: Obvious arete left of the main face.

content.description: Cool little slab, wall, ledges and edges, side pulls, and finger crack.  Start out on long reaches to small in-cuts and insecure feet(moss and lichens)up to a strange glued-in square block, then up edges and ledges to the upper finger crack with slopey ledges for feet!  Super Fun.
content.protection: Small to medium wired stoppers and cams.  There is one crack/pod that would take a size 2-3 C4 cam.
content.location: Right of the route Eagle Dihedral in the Ramsay's Pinnacle area.  Climbs slab/wall over on the right side of this little formation.  This route is not in the most recent Swartling & Mayer and is located right of route 19 page 164 and right of route 19 on diagram 36E page 136.

content.description:
Positive edges up the lower face, delicate and powerful move to grab the big ledge, then ... don't mantle, but use Burt's beta (look left). 

  Lot's o' fun!
content.location: At the bottom of the Ramsey's access gully, skiers right, the final formation has an east facing wall with this route as the left-most, just right of the corner.

content.description: Better than it's neighbor Cut Rate this climb takes some nice balance and footwork. Get to the jug near the arete and then use the arete for a few moves until you can cut left again aiming for the wide flat jug to finish in the middle of the wall.
content.location: Start on the left side of the obvious arete that also includes Cut Rate.

content.description:
Start in the dihedral below the roof, as shown in Nick's photo.  According to Swartling and Mayer, exit the roof to the right ... but there is no gear out that way.  Alternatively, step left onto the big shelf (easy, great gear) or follow the crack slightly left (not the greatest gear). 

  Cross easy ledges to the upper dihedral. 

  The upper dihedral is the crux, especially the last two moves. 

  The crux sews up with a couple of nuts and a 1/4" cam.
Small area with a smattering of moderate climbs, mainly "Ramsay's Pinnacle."
